consent.title: Welcome to Olympics Math Team
content: Math Team scenarios with ability and prediction questions.
This experiment should take about 60 minutes.
Your participation is completely voluntary. You can agree to take part and later change your mind.

content.value: In this experiment, imagine that you are a talent recruiter for math olympiad competitions!

For each tournament, you will have two parts of the task. In the first part, your goal is to guess — based on a single tournament — how talented different athletes are and how much efforts they put in and make predictions about who will win in a new race of the tournament. You can assume all players are young adults (unless otherwise stated).

You will first read a few sentences of background telling you how the competition works.
You will then be told the questions to think about in your talent scout report.
Then, the results of the championship tournament will be revealed!
You will then make your guesses for the questions.

The first two questions will ask you to think about the abilities of the players themselves.
The next two questions will ask you to think about the efforts the players put in.
Then, the last question will ask you to predict the outcomes of a new match.

As with real competitions, anything can happen!
Like a real talent scout, it may be hard to determine exactly how good any athlete is.
This is not a logic puzzle. There is real uncertainty here and no right answer! Make your best guesses and be the best talent scout you can be!

To allow you to express uncertainty in your guesses, we will provide you with a special slider.
On this slider, you can click 5 times to enter in your guesses about the players.

This will let you keep track of information that you might be uncertain about.
For instance, imagine you are asked to reason about the strength of a player in some sport. Let's say you are scouting out Greg.
If you feel confident that Greg is quite strong compared to his peers, you might click 5 times at one end of the scale, like this:
If instead you felt quite uncertain and had little information about Greg, you might click 5 times, widely spreading your guesses around the middle, like this:

Finally, when we ask you to make predictions about new games taking place later on the same day, you will again be able to click up to 5 times to tell us about who you think would win.
For instance, if you thought that Team 2 would definitely beat Team 1, you could move the slider like this:
And if you thought that either Team 1 might win or the game might come out to be close to a tie, you could move the slider like this:

In the second part of the task, we will show you two of the tournaments you read about earlier.
Imagine you are a sports commentator, giving one bit of new information about that tournament.
Your task for each tournament will be to add a new sentence to that tournament that would change ANOTHER talent scout's mind about what happened in that tournament.

We will tell you the effect you should be trying to produce (e.g., whether you should make a certain athlete seem faster than before).
After this experiment, we will show the tournament information (with your new sentence) to new Prolific participants acting as talent scouts!
You will receive a bonus of up to $0.50 if your new sentence changes their guesses in the right way!

One quick caveat — it is pretty easy to come up with commentary that will not make any sense with what you have seen. For instance, if someone is losing a lot, you probably cannot just explain that they are a very good player.
We will also show your sentence to another group of participants who will judge whether the sentence makes sense relative to the original tournament. That is, whether the outcomes are still possible under your commentary.
If it is judged to not be sensible, you may not receive a bonus.

With that said, you should feel free to be as creative as you like!
You can definitely have fun with it, though please try to write something that could actually happen in a real tournament.
For example, you could write about:
  • a specific event that takes place at any time immediately before, during, or after the tournament (e.g., "Just before the first match, Bob's glasses broke.")
  • any important information about a particular player during the tournament today (e.g., "Bob is sick today.")
  • any bio information about a particular player in general (e.g., "Joe has been taking steroids for months.")
If you decide to write a sentence referring to a specific race, be sure to specify which race (e.g., "in the first race" or "after the third race").

Your sentences should be simple enough for anyone else to understand on their own without further explanation.
That is, please do NOT write something like:
Just before the first match, Bob sprained his ankle, which means that he was not as good in that round.

However, just so we understand your thinking, we will ask you to provide a short 2-3 sentence explanation of why you think your sentence will have the desired effect.
But this extra information will NOT be provided to the next set of Prolific participants who read the tournament with your sentence.

You will read a total of 6 scenarios describing tournaments.
Think of each tournament as separate and unrelated to the previous tournaments.
You should not think of the athletes in one tournament as at all related to the athletes in another tournament.
Remember, make your best guesses as you go! We know that some of these scenarios can be a bit tricky! Go with your intuition!
